Generate_examples module

class Generate_examples.RandomTransitionsGenerator(num_tests, directory, num_states=None, num_actions=None, num_vars=None, max_branching_factor=None, num_participants=None, max_num_transitions=None, steps=5, num_example_for_each=5)[source]

Bases: object

Generates random transitions for FSM testing and stores them in files.

Initialization parameters define the configuration for transition generation.

appendToWork(works, i, number_elt)[source]

Appends work items to the list for parallel execution.

merge_and_delete()[source]

Merges individual CSV files into one and cleans up the directory.

run()[source]

Executes the transition generation process.

run2()[source]

An alternative execution mode for generating transitions.

Generate_examples.genFile(directory, subdir_num, max_tests, num_states, num_actions, num_vars, max_branching_factor, num_participants, max_num_transitions)[source]
Generate_examples.generate_a_transition(state_variables, params, participant, role, to_state, from_state, action)[source]

Generates a textual representation of a transition based on the specified parameters.

Parameters:

  • state_variables (list) – A list of tuples representing the state variables involved in the transition, where each tuple contains the variable type and name.

  • params (list) – A list of tuples representing the parameters involved in the transition, where each tuple contains the parameter type and name.

  • participant (str) – The name of the participant involved in the transition.

  • role (str) – The role of the participant in the transition.

  • to_state (str) – The name of the destination state for the transition.

  • from_state (str) – The name of the source state from which the transition occurs.

  • action (str) – The name of the action associated with the transition.

Returns:

A textual representation of the generated transition.

Return type:

str

Generate_examples.generate_actions(max_actions)[source]

Generates a list of unique action names, up to a specified maximum number.

Parameters:

max_actions (int) – The maximum number of unique action names to generate. The actual number of generated action names may be less than this maximum if the specified number exceeds the practical limit for unique names.

Returns:

A list containing unique action names.

Return type:

list

Generate_examples.generate_parameters(max_params)[source]

Generates a list of action parameters with random types, up to a specified maximum number.

Parameters:

max_params (int) – The maximum number of parameters to generate. The actual number of generated parameters may be less than this maximum.

Returns:

A list of tuples, each containing the type and name of a generated parameter.

Return type:

list

Generate_examples.generate_random_type_variables(num_vars)[source]

Generates a list of variables with random types, intended for use in transition generation.

Parameters:

num_vars (int) – The number of variables to generate. Each variable will have a randomly assigned type.

Returns:

A list of tuples, each containing the type and name of a generated variable.

Return type:

list

Generate_examples.generate_secure_seed() → int[source]

Generates a secure seed for random number generation using os.urandom.

Returns:

A securely generated seed that can be used for initializing a random number generator.

Return type:

int

Generate_examples.generate_transitions(num_states, num_actions, num_vars, max_branching_factor, num_participants, max_num_transitions)[source]

Generates a list of textual transitions and associated statistical data based on specified parameters.

Parameters:

  • num_states (int) – The number of states in the FSM.

  • num_actions (int) – The number of actions available for transitions.

  • num_vars (int) – The number of variables involved in the FSM.

  • max_branching_factor (int) – The maximum number of transitions from any given state.

  • num_participants (int) – The number of participants involved in the FSM.

  • max_num_transitions (int) – The maximum number of transitions to be generated.

Returns:

A list containing the generated transitions and statistical data about the generation process.

Return type:

list

Generate_examples.generate_z3_condition(variables, params, complexity)[source]

Generates a Z3 solver condition string based on provided variables, parameters, and specified complexity.

Parameters:

  • variables (list) – A list of state variables available for generating the condition. Each element is a tuple containing the variable type and name.

  • params (list) – A list of parameters available for condition generation. Each element is a tuple containing the parameter type and name.

  • complexity (int) – An integer indicating the complexity level of the generated condition. Higher values result in more complex conditions.

Returns:

A string representing the generated Z3 solver condition.

Return type:

str

Generate_examples.get_generated_stuffs(actions, states, participants, num_vars, roles)[source]

Selects random elements from provided lists to construct a transition.

Parameters:

  • actions (list) – A list of available actions for transitions.

  • states (list) – A list of available states in the FSM.

  • participants (list) – A list of available participants involved in the FSM.

  • num_vars (int) – The number of variables involved in transition conditions.

  • roles (list) – A list of available roles that participants can have.

Returns:

A tuple containing randomly selected action, state, participant, parameters, and role for constructing a transition.

Return type:

tuple

Generate_examples.main()[source]

Main function to parse command-line arguments and trigger transition generation.

Generate_examples.write_file(path, transitions)[source]

Writes the generated transitions to a specified file.

Parameters:

  • path (str) – The file path where the transitions will be written.

  • transitions (list) – A list of transitions to be written to the file.
